stem: A 29-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted with severe vomiting, ataxia (stumbling), and hand tremors. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status changes and GI distress.
Background: Taking lithium carbonate for 2 years. Recently took ibuprofen for back pain and reduced fluid intake due to a 'stomach bug.'
Assessment: Client has an unsteady gait, slurred speech, and coarse tremors in both hands.
Recommendation: Stabilization of fluids and likely dialysis if level is critical.

tabs.title: Critical Lab Results
tabs.content:
TestFindingSignificance
Serum Lithium2.6 mEq/LCritical High (>1.5 mEq/L is toxic)
Serum Sodium132 mEq/L (Low)Risk factor for lithium retention
Creatinine1.9 mg/dL (High)Acute Kidney Injury

tabs.title: Neuro Assessment
tabs.content: Presence of coarse tremors. Ataxic gait (positive Romberg). Confusion to time and place.

actionOptions.text: Immediately hold all scheduled doses of lithium
Initiate IV 0.9% normal saline at 150 mL/hr
Administer an extra dose of sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)
Administer diazepam for alcohol withdrawal prevention

parameterOptions.text: Serial serum lithium and creatinine levels
Lithium dose timing and peak flow meter

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing severe lithium toxicity (c2) (Level 2.6 mEq/L). Symptoms include coarse tremors, ataxia, and slurred speech. Risk factors include hyponatremia and NSAID use (ibuprofen), both of which decrease renal clearance of lithium. Priority actions: Stop the drug (a1) and administer IV normal saline (a2) to help the kidneys excrete the lithium. Monitoring renal function/lithium levels (p1) and neurological status (p2) is vital.
clinicalPearls: Lithium level > 2.5 mEq/L often requires hemodialysis.
NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) are contraindicated with lithium because they cause the kidneys to retain lithium.
Low sodium = High lithium. The body sees lithium as a sodium substitute and retains it if sodium is low.

questionTrap.trap: Encouraging a low-sodium diet in this patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Low sodium makes lithium toxicity worse. Lithium patients must maintain adequate sodium and fluid intake.

mnemonic.title: Toxicity Triad
mnemonic.expansion: G-Gait instability. I-Incessant N/V. N-Neuro (Coarse Tremors).
